Award.AwardTitle: PARTNERS FOR SUCCESS: Building Partnerships to Increase Success of Underrepresented Minorities in Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This planning project entitled PARTNERS FOR SUCCESS: Building Partnerships to Increase Success of Underrepresented Minorities in Physics at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) is developing an innovative model to attract, retain, and bridge underrepresented minority students to graduate school in physics. The project aims to develop partnerships between Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) and degree granting institutions. The main idea is to develop a well-structured mentoring and support model between the participating institutions that will be institutionalized for sustainable impact.

Attention is paid to the students' steps of the path, from pre to post baccalaureate. The project seeks to first attract students to the discipline and then provide them with effective mentoring and a wealth of research opportunities at the MSI. Then in partnership with doctoral degree granting institutions, students are assisted in overcoming the challenges they face in obtaining a doctoral degree in physics. Although this model will be implemented at the UTEP, a Hispanic Serving Institution, it has the potential to impact underrepresented minority students throughout the nation due to its transferability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Partners for Success (PASS) is a bridge model based on the partnership between a Minority Serving Institution (MSI) and Doctorate Granting Institutions (DGIs) to attract, retain, and increase the number of underrepresented minority (URM) students bridging to a doctoral program in physics. In contrast to most of the bridge programs implemented at various institutions in the US, this initiative not only concentrates on training physics master students, but it also targets physics undergraduates under the premise that proactive mentoring, cohort building, and good and challenging research opportunities can serve to retain students in their bachelor program, but also motivate them to continue toward graduate education and eventually earn a Physics PhD. The implementation of this project was done as a partnership of the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP), a MSI, and several DGIs, as the University of Arizona, University of Texas at Austin, University of Chicago, University of California Davis, and MIT.

In the PASS model, the “bridging” started in the baccalaureate years through research experiences for cohorts of undergraduates at the MSI and DGIs, networking and visits of DGI and MSI mentors, and involvement of the students in research collaborations with mentors from the MSI and the partner institutions. In addition, the model featured bridging graduate courses taken at the MSI, and courses offered online by the partner DGIs. The approach developed proved to be particularly effective in helping underrepresented minority students to gain the self-confidence and preparation they needed to fully develop their potential, thereby providing the psychological bridging required to adapt to the challenges they had to face when moving to the environment of a PhD program in a DGI.

Overall, the PASS project involved 23 participants, all of whom took advantage of the mentorship, proactive advising, and research opportunities both at the MSI and DGIs. Even though the grant could fund stipends for just 11 of these students, the PASS project was quite successful. It managed to bridge 100% of the master students into top Physics PhD programs; from the group of undergraduate participants who earned their bachelor degree during the project implementation, 57% transitioned directly to a Physics PhD, and 42% decided to enter in a master program as a bridge toward the PhD. There are still 6 undergraduates who have not yet finished their physics bachelor. All of them are progressing well toward timely graduation in the next two years and have expressed their determination to continue toward graduate school with the final goal of a Physics PhD. 87% of the students in the project are Hispanics and 23% are women, so this project has had an impact in easing the lack of diverse representation in the physics discipline. 

In summary, the PASS project has been very effective in retaining URM students in their physics bachelor, in bridging the master students to PhD in Physics, and in motivating others to enter in a master program as a first step to eventually bridging them to the PhD.

The intellectual merit of the PASS project lies in the innovative, flexible, and potentially transformative model of partnership, mentoring, and research training that has been shown to increase the success of URM in physics. The flexibility of the partnerships allowed within the PASS model multiplies the number of pathways available to students interested in a PhD, and allows the mentors to specially tailor activities to meet the needs and talents of different students. Although the model was implemented and tested at the University of Texas at El Paso, a Hispanic Serving Institution, the synergy created by its main elements should be easily adopted by other institutions, because it does not need a near-by DGI, nor does it require the same bridge component or the same level of commitment from each participating DGI, making this a viable model for a wide range of universities.

The broader impact of the PASS project, apart from the number of students who have already benefited from its implementation at UTEP, comes from its capacity to impact URMs throughout the nation thanks to its transferability. This characteristic and the fact that the bridge training is conducted in the minority serving institution and not at a particular DGI enable this model to benefit a large number of physics students.
